prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity: As detailed in the Scientific Justification, our goal is to reach a continuum sensitivity at 345GHz of 0.2mJy (4 sigma). At the requested angular resolution, ~0.5arcsec, or 60-80AU at the distance of our targets, we do not expect to significantly resolve the emission and we require an rms sensitivity of 0.05 mJy/beam. We have selected a correlator setup with three wide TDM bands for continuum sensitivity and higher spectral resolution band to cover the co(3-2) line (with the same bandwidth coverage, as compared to a continuum-only setup). We do expect to reach the goal noise level in 15-20 minutes on source, depending on the target elevation.
Imaging requirements: We do not expect to image the targets, we have no strong constraints on the (u,v) coverage. The observations are best done with 0.5arcsec resolution which offer the possiblity of showing extended emission if the disks are brighter than expected. The integration time is defined by our goal sensitivity, nit by (u,v) coverage constraints.
Correlator setup: We are primarily interested in detecting the dust continuum emission at 345GHz, we have thus selected a setup with three wide low resolution spectral windows plus a higher resolution band, these offer a total aggregated bandwidth of 7.5GHz per polarization (the maximum possible bandwidth). The higher resolution spectral window include the CO(3-2) line whose emission may be detected if present in the young debris disks, although this is not our primary goal and we do not expect that the targets will show a prominent gas emission. If line emission is present, the expected linewidth is 1-2 km/s, we will thus not resolve the line in velocity.
Time constraints: None
``User-defined'' calibration: None

Imaging requirements: We do not expect to image the targets, we have no strong constraints on the (u,v) coverage. If line emission is present, the expected linewidth is 1-2 km/s, we will thus not resolve the line in velocity.
Time constraints: None
``User-defined'' calibration: None

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ClassIII_Tau_2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Class III objects in Taurus HBC_388

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Single solar mass stars are all expected to form with a relatively massive circumstellar disk as a result of angular momentum conservation during collapse. Planetary systems are formed in these disks in the majority of systems, as indicated by exoplanets searches. Typical lifetimes of disks (~3 Myr) set the typical timescale for planet formation, however, even in the youngest star forming regions, the fraction of stars without a massive disk is significant. It is thus possible that, in some cases, planet formation and outer disk photoevaporation occur on much faster timescales (<1Myr) than currently envisaged. We propose to search for young debris disks, the remnants of this early planet formation process, in a sample of single diskless solar-mass young stars in the Ophiuchus and Taurus star forming regions. Our observations are designed to produce stringent limits on the possible existence of these debris disks and will be able to conclusively prove or disprove the hypothesis of early planet formation through the core-accretion process.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Physics Mathematics and Astronomy, California Institute of Technology
Institute for Astronomy, Hawaii at Manoa, University of
